item.title: N.S. to release daily details on schools affected by COVID-19 starting Tuesday
item.description: Elizabeth Guitard kept her kids home from school Monday, concerned over the growing list of COVID-19 exposures linked to Nova Scotia schools.
item.dc:creator: Heidi Petracek
item.enclosure: According to one parent, at least one school affected by multiple exposures is now taking extra measures. One parent whose child attends Halifax West says she received four separate notifications about cases connected to the school.

item.title: Stop asking staff to write fake vaccine records: New Brunswick Horizon Health

item.dc:creator: Samantha Long
item.enclosure: Horizon Health in New Brunswick has issued a notice telling the public to stop asking public health to falsify vaccination documentation.

item.title: P.E.I. reports two new cases of COVID-19 Tuesday, active cases drop to nine
item.description: Prince Edward Island is reporting two new cases of COVID-19 on Tuesday, as the active number of cases in the province drops to nine.
item.dc:creator: Allan April
item.enclosure: “Since August, 87 per cent of the cases in P.E.I. have been identified as the Delta variant,” said Dr. Heather Morrison, P.E.I.’s Chief Public Health Officer, during Tuesday’s news update.

item.title: RCMP end search for two Labrador fishermen reported missing more than a week ago
item.description: The RCMP in southeastern Labrador have called off the search for two fishermen whose boat disappeared more than a week ago.
item.dc:creator: The Canadian Press
item.enclosure: The fishing vessel Island Lady is shown in this undated handout image provided by Dwight Russell. The father of a missing fisherman is asking the coast guard to resume a full search effort in hopes of recovering his son and one crew member of a nine-metre boat that went missing on Friday off the coast of Labrador. THE CANADIAN PRESS/HO-Dwight Russell

item.title: Crown wraps case against first six inmates accused in vicious N.S. jail assault
item.description: The Crown closed its case Tuesday in the first of three trials involving Nova Scotia inmates accused of conspiring and attempting to murder a newly arrived prisoner.
item.dc:creator: The Canadian Press
item.enclosure: Crown prosecutor Rick Woodburn, right, talks with Andrew Miller, a senior corrections official at the trial for six of the 15 inmates accused of participating in a vicious assault of another prisoner at a Nova Scotia jail, at a convention centre in Halifax on Wednesday, Sept. 22, 2021. The victim sustained life-threatening injuries in the Dec. 2, 2019 attack at the Central Nova Scotia Correctional Facility in Dartmouth. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Andrew Vaughan

item.title: 'Residents are dying alone,' nursing home workers ask for wage increase to help staffing crisis
item.description: During a virtual news conference on Monday, the union representing workers in many of New Brunswick's nursing homes is urging premier Blaine Higgs to fix the current "staffing crisis" in nursing homes across the province.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Basa
item.enclosure: The president of the New Brunswick Council of Nursing Home Unions, which represents 51 of 70 nursing homes in the province, says several locations across the province have been operating with 50 per cent of their staff or less, which doesn't allow them to prioritize those in their care.
